title: Chinese Government cancels $50.37 million of the Government of Yemen’s outstanding obligations
description: On November 6, 2002, the Chinese Government and the Government of Yemen signed a partial debt exemption protocol agreement (中华人民共和国政府和也门共和国政府关于免除也门共和国部分债务的议定书). The agreement reportedly stipulated that the Chinese Government would forgive the Yemeni Government’s outstanding obligations under seven loans that it contracted between the years of 1958 and 1989. Several media sources indicate that the Chinese Government agreed to forgive $84 million in total (out of Yemen’s total outstanding debt to China of $185 million). However, Yemen’s Central Bank reports that $50.37 million was forgiven during 2002. AidData relies upon the value reported by Yemen’s Central Bank.
staff_comments: 1. One source indicates that the Chinese Government previously agreed in 2001 to exempt the Yemeni Government from repaying RMB 75.9 million of debt (from loans that it contracted between 1958 and 1972). However, it is unclear if these are separate debts from those covered by the November 6, 2002 partial debt exemption protocol agreement. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels $50.37 million of the Government of Yemen’s outstanding obligations

# Description
On November 6, 2002, the Chinese Government and the Government of Yemen signed a partial debt exemption protocol agreement (中华人民共和国政府和也门共和国政府关于免除也门共和国部分债务的议定书). The agreement reportedly stipulated that the Chinese Government would forgive the Yemeni Government’s outstanding obligations under seven loans that it contracted between the years of 1958 and 1989. Several media sources indicate that the Chinese Government agreed to forgive $84 million in total (out of Yemen’s total outstanding debt to China of $185 million). However, Yemen’s Central Bank reports that $50.37 million was forgiven during 2002. AidData relies upon the value reported by Yemen’s Central Bank.
justification: Debt forgiveness is a financial transaction without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt cancellation agreement, no specific project or environmental impact mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 69.2 million interest-free loan for Kamwala Government Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#30472, #15411)
description: On September 16, 2002, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 69.2 million interest-free loan to the Government of Zambia for the Kamwala Government Complex Construction Project.  Then, in 2009, China Eximbank provided an additional $25 million loan (captured via Project #30472) to the Government of Zambia when the original funding proved insufficient to undertake the project. In August 2010, the Chinese government provided additional grant funding for the project (captured via Project ID#15411).  The project involved the construction of a government complex is located in Lusaka. Construction was initiated by China Overseas Engineering Company (COVEC) and completed by Shanghai Construction Company. Construction was originally expected to take 14 months from the implementation start date. However, in 2009, China Eximbank Construction began on March 1, 2010 and ended on August 31, 2011. The project was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on held on January 13, 2012.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the New Government Complex or Zambia Government Building Conference Center and Banquet Hall. The Chinese project title is 赞比亚政府综合楼项目 or 赞比亚政府大楼会议中心和宴会厅.2. Since the borrowing terms of the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set the maturity to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default, per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 69.2 million interest-free loan for Kamwala Government Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#30472, #15411)

# Description
On September 16, 2002, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 69.2 million interest-free loan to the Government of Zambia for the Kamwala Government Complex Construction Project.  Then, in 2009, China Eximbank provided an additional $25 million loan (captured via Project #30472) to the Government of Zambia when the original funding proved insufficient to undertake the project. In August 2010, the Chinese government provided additional grant funding for the project (captured via Project ID#15411).  The project involved the construction of a government complex is located in Lusaka. Construction was initiated by China Overseas Engineering Company (COVEC) and completed by Shanghai Construction Company. Construction was originally expected to take 14 months from the implementation start date. However, in 2009, China Eximbank Construction began on March 1, 2010 and ended on August 31, 2011. The project was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on held on January 13, 2012.
justification: Project involves construction of government office complex without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Government complex construction, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government donates 4,500 tons of yellow maize to Zambia for famine relief
description: On August 6, 2002, the Chinese Government agreed to donate 4,500 tons of yellow maize to the Government of Zambia to alleviate famine. The monetary value of this donation is unknown. The purpose of this donation was to help the Zambian authorities deal with a shortfall of about 175,000 tons of maize. The maize was officially delivered and handed over to the authorities on September 16, 2003.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government donates 4,500 tons of yellow maize to Zambia for famine relief

# Description
On August 6, 2002, the Chinese Government agreed to donate 4,500 tons of yellow maize to the Government of Zambia to alleviate famine. The monetary value of this donation is unknown. The purpose of this donation was to help the Zambian authorities deal with a shortfall of about 175,000 tons of maize. The maize was officially delivered and handed over to the authorities on September 16, 2003.
justification: Project is a humanitarian food donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 4,500 tons of yellow maize donated for famine relief, social development focus

title: Chinese Government donates 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer worth RMB 20 million
description: In August 2002, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the Government of Zambia with 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer worth RMB 20 million (about USD $2.5 million). Zambia’s Foreign Minister Kalombo Mwansa and China’s Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu attended the agreement signing ceremony. The handover ceremony occurred on September 16, 2003.
combined_text:

Zambia’s Foreign Minister Kalombo Mwansa and China’s Ambassador to Zambia Peng Keyu attended the agreement signing ceremony. The handover ceremony occurred on September 16, 2003.
justification: Fertilizer donation is a social development project without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 7,780 metric tons of fertilizer donation, agricultural support focus

title: Chinese Government grants RMB 3.82 million for Lusaka and Kitwe Radio Stations Maintenance Project
description: On December 31, 2001 and January 21, 2002, the Chinese government and the Government of Zambia signed letters of exchange related to the Lusaka and Kitwe Radio Stations Maintenance Project. The Chinese government committed RMB 3.8 million in grant funding for the provision of two FM transmitters to the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC) for its radio 1 and radio 2 channels. Shanxi Construction Engineering Group was the contractor responsible for implementation, and this project was officially completed and handed over to the Zambian authorities on September 8, 2005. Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong and Zambian Minister of Information and Broadcasting Services Vernon Mwaanga presided over the official handover ceremony.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 赞比亚卢萨卡、基特韦电台维修项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
Chinese Government grants RMB 3.82 million for Lusaka and Kitwe Radio Stations Maintenance Project

# Description
On December 31, 2001 and January 21, 2002, the Chinese government and the Government of Zambia signed letters of exchange related to the Lusaka and Kitwe Radio Stations Maintenance Project. The Chinese government committed RMB 3.8 million in grant funding for the provision of two FM transmitters to the Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation (ZNBC) for its radio 1 and radio 2 channels. Shanxi Construction Engineering Group was the contractor responsible for implementation, and this project was officially completed and handed over to the Zambian authorities on September 8, 2005. Chinese Ambassador to Zambia Li Baodong and Zambian Minister of Information and Broadcasting Services Vernon Mwaanga presided over the official handover ceremony.
justification: Project focuses on maintenance and upgrade of communication infrastructure without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Radio station maintenance, provision of FM transmitters, communications sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million loan in 2002 Special Train Loan for TAZARA Operations and Maintenance Project
description: In 1967, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 494 million interest-free loan to the Government of Zambia for the construction of the 1860 km Tanzania–Zambia Railway (TAZARA), stretching from Dar‑es‑Salaam to Kapiri Mposhi. Since then, the Chinese Government has provided a series of grants and loans to support TAZARA by providing spare parts, fuel, technical assistance, passenger coaches, and locomotives. On December 31, 2002, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 50 million loan to support the ongoing operations and maintenance of TAZARA. This project is known as the Special Train Loan.
staff_comments: 1. Since the borrowing terms of the interest-free loan are unavailable, AidData has set the maturity to 20 years by default and grace period to 10 years by default, per China's Foreign Assistance White Paper (http://www.cidca.gov.cn/2018-08/06/c_129925064_3.htm) which states that the maturity of interest-free loans is 20 years, with a drawdown period of 5 years, grace period of 5 years, and repayment over 10 years. AidData treats the drawdown period as providing 5 years of additional grace.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 50 million loan in 2002 Special Train Loan for TAZARA Operations and Maintenance Project

# Description
In 1967, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 494 million interest-free loan to the Government of Zambia for the construction of the 1860 km Tanzania–Zambia Railway (TAZARA), stretching from Dar‑es‑Salaam to Kapiri Mposhi. Since then, the Chinese Government has provided a series of grants and loans to support TAZARA by providing spare parts, fuel, technical assistance, passenger coaches, and locomotives. On December 31, 2002, the Chinese Government provided an RMB 50 million loan to support the ongoing operations and maintenance of TAZARA. This project is known as the Special Train Loan.
justification: Project focuses on railway operations and maintenance without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Railway operations and maintenance, provision of spare parts, fuel, technical assistance, passenger coaches, and locomotives

title: Chinese Government donates sports equipment worth 2 million ZWL to the Zimbabwe’s Ministry of Sports and Culture
description: On January 4, 2002, the Chinese Government donated sports equipment worth 2 million ZWL to the Zimbabwean Ministry of Sports and Culture.  The donation was handed to Enias Chigwedere, the Zimbabwean Minister of Education, Sports, and Culture, by Hou Qingru, the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe.  The donation was specifically slated for the Sport Administrators of tennis, football, rugby, and volleyball.
combined_text:

The donation was handed to Enias Chigwedere, the Zimbabwean Minister of Education, Sports, and Culture, by Hou Qingru, the Chinese Ambassador to Zimbabwe.  The donation was specifically slated for the Sport Administrators of tennis, football, rugby, and volleyball.
justification: Project is a donation of sports equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact

title: Chinese Government donates goods worth 1.9 million Zimbabwean dollars to City of Harare Mayor's 'Christmas Cheer Fund’
description: In November 2002, the Chinese Embassy handed over 1.9 million Zimbabwean dollars worth of goods to the City of Harare Mayor's 'Christmas Cheer Fund'.  The exchange occurred between the Mayor's wife, Jabu Mudzuri and the wife of the Chinese Ambassador, Zaofen Yuan.  The donation consisted of 500kg of rice, 100 baby blankets, 100 stationery kits (school bags and pencils etc), 100 t-shirts, 50 toys, and sweets.  The donations will eventually benefit the city's orphans and needy. This project is completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government donates goods worth 1.9 million Zimbabwean dollars to City of Harare Mayor's 'Christmas Cheer Fund’

# Description
In November 2002, the Chinese Embassy handed over 1.9 million Zimbabwean dollars worth of goods to the City of Harare Mayor's 'Christmas Cheer Fund'.  The exchange occurred between the Mayor's wife, Jabu Mudzuri and the wife of the Chinese Ambassador, Zaofen Yuan.  The donation consisted of 500kg of rice, 100 baby blankets, 100 stationery kits (school bags and pencils etc), 100 t-shirts, 50 toys, and sweets.  The donations will eventually benefit the city's orphans and needy. This project is completed.
justification: Project is a social welfare donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of food, clothing, and school supplies to support orphans and needy populations

title: Chinese Government dispatches 9th medical team to Harare Central Hospital and Mpilo Central Hospital
description: On 19 December, 2002, the 9th medical team arrived in Zimbabwe.  The 9th medical team consisted of 12 members, and they were stationed at Harare Central Hospital and Mpilo Central Hospital.  They completed their term of service between 19 December, 2002 and early 2005. The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Zimbabwe every two years since 1985.  Hunan Province has been responsible for sending the teams.
combined_text:

They completed their term of service between 19 December, 2002 and early 2005. The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to Zimbabwe every two years since 1985.  Hunan Province has been responsible for sending the teams.

title: Chinese Government provides $3.8 million grant for transport sector activities (linked to #61278 and #16840)
description: In 2002, the Chinese Government provided a $4.8 million grant to the Government of Zimbabwe, which is captured in the linked project #16840. The $4.8 million grant had two parts: a $3.8 million grant and a $1 million grant.  This project captures the $3.8 million grant, which was intended for use in Zimbabwe's transport sector.  The remaining $1 million grant was used for the purchase of agricultural inputs and animal vaccines (captured in linked project #61278).
combined_text:
